description.narrative: To assist the government in (i) improving the efficiency and effectiveness of governance processes in the management of public finances, (ii) promoting transparency and accountability in the performance of public sector functions, and (iii) fostering the investment climate in Mongolia.

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Article IV, para. 4.01 (a) | Description :The Recipient shall have established the Project Coordination Unitpursuant to provisions of paragraph 1 of Section I of Schedule 2to this Agreement. | Due Date :21-Sep-2006

Finance Agreement :Article IV, para. 4.01 (b) | Description :The Recipient shall have adopted the Project Financial Manual pursuantto paragraph B.1 of Section II of Schedule 2 to this Agreement. | Due Date :21-Sep-2006

Finance Agreement :Schedule 2, Section I, para. 3 | Description :The Recipient shall by August 31, 2006, adopt and thereafter applyin the implementation manual, satisfactory to the Association. | Due Date :31-Aug-2006

title.narrative: Improved public accountability as evidenced by:(i) reduced perception of corruption and (ii) an effective conflict of interest framework that complies with UNCAC.

baseline.value: The perception of corruption is on the rise in Mongolia, as reflected in various studies and surveys (e.g. investment climateassessment (ICA),USAID corruption report, WBI indicators).

comment.narrative: The IAAC developed the Mongolian Corruption Index in 2009, based on quantitative (perception surveys) and qualitative indicatorstomonitor corruption. MCI is authorized in the Anti-corruption law and measured every 2 years. MCI is on scale of 0-1, with highernumber reflecting lower corruption
Reduced perception of corruption as measured by increase in the Mongolia Corruption Index
No progress between 2009 and 2011 as measured by the MCI. Next survey in December 2013.

title.narrative: Improvement in Public Access to Key Fiscal Information (PEFA PI-10).

baseline.value: Open Budget Index score of 18 in 2006

comment.narrative: The International Budget Partnership#s Open Budget Survey (OBI) assesses the availability and the comprehensiveness of budgetdocuments in each country based on expert opinion.
Mongolia's OBI ranking fell in the 2012 survey and the target was not achieved

title.narrative: Improved IC as evidenced by:(i)reduced proportion of firms perceiving corruption as a major obstacle to investment and (ii)reduced cost of compliance for business taxpayers [among pilot group]

baseline.value: (i) ICA and (ii) Currently, GDNT audits ALL taxpayers on a 2-3 year cycle, leading to about 10,700 annual audits from a pool of26,400 taxpayers (or 41%).

target.value: (i) Future ICAs show a reduction in proportion of firms perceiving corruption as an obstacle to investment and (ii) reduction ofaudits to lessthan 25%

actual.value: (i) 49.8% of business taxpayers perceive corruption as a major obstacle to investment.(ii) e-filing of VAT, CIt, and PIT at 94%,72%, and 61% respectively

comment.narrative: Corruption perception based on survey by Global Reach Center in December 2011

title.narrative: GFMIS rollout and better control over budget execution.

baseline.value: No comprehensive monitoring of debt situation

actual.value: Upgrading of DMFAS from 5.3 to 6.0 completed

title.narrative: Efficient operation of the Mining Registry and Cadastre system

baseline.value: No computerized cadastre system; management of mineral licenses arbitrary and non-transparent

target.value: Increased public access to the mining cadastre to further enhance transparency

title.narrative: Improved and expanded disclosure of key GDNT data.

baseline.value: GDNT publishes taxpayer assistance information and information about rulings, taxes and guidelines.

target.value: GDNT publishes and disseminates (i) taxpayer assistance information; (ii) customer satisfaction and (iii) comprehensive statementof taxpayers'rights.

actual.value: All information for taxpayers which set in the list has been posted in the GDNT’s website accordingly. Customer’s satisfactionsurvey conducted in annual basis and the results published on the website regularly.

title.narrative: LSMS data readily available to the Public.

baseline.value: LSMS data is accessible in theory but access is difficult in practice and not advertised.

actual.value: Achieved. HSES available on annual bases. Dynamic database of LSMS created.ii) LSMS raw data disseminated to the public by onlineand paper based regimes.

title.narrative: Functional system of income and asset declaration and disclosure.

target.value: Detailed assets and income declarations continue to be published. Improved analysis of IAD through functional Asset and IncomeDeclaration Information System

actual.value: Achieved. 100% compliance rate and new online system for AID and CoI declarations functional

comment.narrative: AIDIS modified into personal interest, asset and income declaration information system (PIAIDIS) by July 2013 which based ononlineregime. The system is functional.

title.narrative: Improved investment climate as evidenced by increased use of open competition in public procurement.

baseline.value: Sound legal framework. 2006 Procurement Law based on international best practiceWeak Procurement Monitoring System.

comment.narrative: Significant increase in use of direct contracting for procurements financed by Chinggis bond proceeds and implemented byDevelopment Bank of Mongolia

title.narrative: Improved efficiency and effectiveness of management of public finance framework as evidenced by more efficient monitoring of the debt situation based on the adoption of the debt strategy.

baseline.value: There is no formal Strategy for Debt Management in place and no comprehensive monitoring of debt situation.

target.value: A Public Debt Strategy (PDS) is developed; adopted and used as a critical tool for Govt. to make sound fiscal policy decision. Acomprehensivemonitoring of the debt mgt to ensure sustainability.

comment.narrative: End target will be the effective implementation of the Debt management strategy (2012-2014)

actual.value: Partially achieved. Medium-term debt management strategy (MTDMS) prepared and being regularly updated. However, Ministry ofEconomic Development issued Chinggis bond in 2012 without reference to the MTDMS. Hence implementation of the strategy is weak.

comment.narrative: First medium-term debt management strategy/MTDMS for2007-2009 developed and adopted by Finance minister order #144 which dated onMay 24, 2007. The strategy has been revised in every two years as set forth in the law of Mongolia and the MTDMS for 2010-2012 hasbeen adopted by Finance Minister order #219 dated on October 01, 2010 and the MTDMS for 2012-2014 adopted by Finance Minister order#26 dated on January 20, 2012.
